messageText: Hello?
This is Pavlovsky, aboard the Soyuz 3.
Does the Baikonur read me?
A. This is the Soviet Baikonur.
B. What's your status?
x
Right, of course. Sorry, we hadn't run into interference problems before.
Anosova and Burkov are currently completing the EVA.
The EVA?
What caused the interference?
Yeah, the spacewalk that'll push the Soviet Union years ahead in the space race.
Commander Burkov reports that Anosova is finished repairing the UCs and is now onto the UTs.  Vasiliev is aligning the Soyuz with the satellite in…
I'm running some tests now.  Unfortunately, it will be hard to narrow down until we've landed.
Vasilev is preparing the satellite now. It should be smooth sailing shortly.
The Americans will be shaking their heads when they realize how far ahead we are. At this rate, we'll have someone on the moon within the decade.
We will be connecting with the satellite in...
Three...
Two...
One...
We can either attempt to unlatch the satellite, though that may compromise the integrity of the hull --
Or we can get our people to safety first, which may mean losing the satellite altogether!
Get them inside!
Detach the satellite!
Right, will do!  Heading down to the airlock now.
Anosova has entered, waiting on Burkov.
His suit has expanded! Are we safe to just pull him in? Or should he risk deflating it?
Deflate the suit first.
Pull him in!
It's going to be risky. I'll radio him.
His suit's deflating... Almost there...
He's in! A little short of breath, but they're both alive!
Now it seems our only problem is that we've re-entered Earth's atmosphere…
Whether or not we like it -- We're going to have to land.
Get that satellite off!
Prepare to land!
Kamkin's working on the disengage.
It's stuck on something --
CRRRRRSH
Uh, so that wasn't the most graceful of disengagements... But, hey, it's off.
Landing thrusters have slowed our fall. Anosova is deploying the parachute --
CER-CHUNK!
Okay‚ We're deploying the emergency parachute, now!
The ship is still plummeting! The parachute is stuck; it needs a manual override.
Vasiliev's the mechanic, send him!
Kamkin's the most nimble, pick him.
We're nearing the surface, Vasilev should be able to hit the parachute --
...ZzZzZzZz...
[Signal weak]
[Soyuz signal lost]
Unlatch it? Okay, we'll do our best.
The interference is still an issue. We can attempt to do it from here, though it may not connect.
Or should the astronauts attempt to do it manually?
Do it from inside the ship.
Manually is better.
Kamkin has initiated the disengagement. It should only take a few seconds.
...And we're good! Let's hope that's enough.
fzzzzzzsh
Anosova!? Burkov!?
What happened?
What was that sound?
We-- We've entered Earth's atmosphere...
They're both gone.
Oh, mother.
Re-entry?
Gone? There's no way.
We can't land this without them! We need them --
KER-CHUNK
FZZZZSH
[Connection lost]
Burkov and Anosova are working on it. The manual process is pretty straightforward.
Only it has a pretty high-error rate, due to the hull of the ship, behind a paper-thin barrier between us and the vacuum of space.
It seems like they've got it.
Now for the push-off. And we're --
Zzzup
[Connection lost]
Are you sure? I wouldn't want to snag the suit.
Anosova's trying now.
It's stuck, I'm not sure we can get him to fit by pulling.
Try deflating.
Keep pulling.
We'll give it another go.
zip
It's caught on something -- I'll get a closer look.
Zzzup
[Connection lost]
We're getting ready now! The thrusters are prepped, as are the parachutes. It'll be a rough landing with the extra weight, but we should be able to pull it off.
We're nearing the proper altitude for the thrusters... In one moment...
And Vasilev has ignited the thrusters!
Kamkin is headed through the maintenance shaft now. He should be able to activate the emergency parachute momentarily--
You went spiraling off into space and died a horrible death.  Sorry.
I was worried that our signal had been highjacked by the Americans.
Kamkin is monitoring vitals while Vasiliev is preparing to connect with the satellite.
And we've connected!
Excellent work, Soyuz-3!
Get moving on repairing that satellite.
We're getting sporadic readings here.
Elaborate.
Nothing's wrong on our end.
Our monitors show that we've left the 3% drift margin.
Which would mean we're headed into Earth's atmosphere…
That's impossible.
Your readings are wrong.
I respectfully disagree --
Cer-Chunk
Burkov's suit blew open a hole in the airlock, sucking you into space. Brutal way to go.
Pavlovsky's a pretty poor pilot.
Uh, hold on Baikonur...
Chapter 1
Anosova wakes
Drip... Drip...
Drip.
Ughhhhh.
My head pounds like a drum...
Where am I?
What happened?
The maintenance shaft... We crashed..?
I remember releasing the emergency parachute. After that...
I must have been thrown back against the piping.
How am I still alive? My shoulder is killing me.
Oh. My shoulder's bleeding badly. Is it from hitting the pipe?
I gotta get out of here, but the way back looks blocked.
I could try to move the debris, but it also looks like I could fit through where the parachutes were released.
Try the shaft back.
Go out the parachute hole.
Holy shit, that is heavy.
There is no way I'm getting back through here.
Keep trying.
Give up. Try the parachute hole.
Hah Hah. That was way harder than it should have been.
But on the bright side, I'm back in the control hub. Although, it's considerably less-right-way-up now.
The chairs are hanging from the ceiling...
Hold on.
Someone is still strapped into their seat. It's Pavlovsky! He's unconscious or --
SHIT.
Okay...  It's alright, Pavlovsky just fell forward. He surprised me, that's all.
"Anosova..." He wheezes.
Oh man, I should help him down. He does not look well.
Be careful!
That does not look comfortable.
"Alright, easy does it, Pavlovsky."
"Oof, you're heavier than you look."
Have you seen the others?
Did you break anything?
"You're the first..." He gets out before a coughing fit overwhelms him.
Pavlovsky needs medical attention. So do I, for that matter.
Although... The door to the Soyuz was blown off on impact. I could check if I can find anyone else first?
Check outside.
Investigate inside the Soyuz.
Quit exploring
There's a trail of disturbed snow leading away from the ship...
Let's see where it goes.
Wow, it's freezing out here. This jumpsuit was not built for the Siberian wilderness.
Drip...
What was that..?
Drip.
There're a couple crimson drops in the snow. They look like blood...
Drip.
Fuck… It's Kamkin.
He's impaled on a tree branch like two stories in the air...
His lower half is only holding on by his--his tendons.
I'm going to be sick... Oh, God...
...There's a trail over here... Could Burkov have?
But I should try to get him down first, right? It doesn't feel right leaving him up in the tree like that.
Follow the trail.
Climb the tree.
The snow's getting deeper this way.
It's way too cold out.
If I get out of this, I swear I'll never complain about it being too hot again.
There's someone over here!
It's Burkov!
He's not in good shape, though. His side's all torn up.
But...
There's a pulse!
Hey! Burkov, wake up!
"Anosova..? You're alive?" He mutters.
"Damn straight, I'm alive."
How the hell did you get out here?
What happened to your side?
"The pressure of re-entry -- It blew the door off the ship. I was sucked out as we were landing."
"I landed on the door. I think it took most of the force."
"Where the hell are we..?"
"That's an excellent question."
"So, you don't know?"
"Let's just get you back to the ship, and we can figure that out."
There's something on the tree over there. Like claw marks or something.
Investigate claw marks.
Help Burkov back.
They're deep -- Most of the bark is gone. Something tells me they're fresh.
I don't like it here. Let's get Burkov back.
The snow sure doesn't make it easy, but Burkov's not as bad as he looks.
We were able to hobble back to the ship in one piece.
"Anosova?" Pavlovsky calls from inside the ship. Any luck?"
Burkov's still breathing. I can't say the same for Vasiliev.
"I've got some good news. I found our last cosmonaut," Pavlovsky says.
"Kamkin! I can't believe you're alive. "
"Has anyone ever told you, your hugs are suffocating," Kamkin says.
I'm sorry, I was worried you had...
You're just going to have to suck it up.
"Yeah... I know. I'm sorry about Vasiliev."
"You're the boss."
"You should have Pavlovsky look at that shoulder. He found a medkit while you were out."
Let Pavlovsky look at it.
Do it yourself.
"Sit down over here. It's going to sting a little."
"How much is a lit--"
"Good, God! Mother of..."
"I suppose you could say it's relative."
"Relative to what? Being shot? "
"You're welcome."
"Thank you. "
"We're going to have to form a plan," Burkov says, "But you should take time some time to scavenge for supplies first if you want."
Continue scavenging.
We've searched enough, let's come up with a plan.
It looks like there are two sections to explore on the ship: the airlock and the storage compartment.
Search airlock.
Search storage compartment.
Return to Hub
Okay, let's get down to that airlock.
Huh. The door's jammed. It looks like crash warped the frame. There must be another way to get inside.
I'll need to find a way around.
I thought the rest of the ship was in rough shape... The storage looks like a tornado ripped through.
It looks like some of the drawers are undamaged.
Though, I could climb into the maintenance shaft from here, which could get me access to other parts of the ship.
Search the drawers.
Try the maintenance shaft.
Return to Hub.
Hmm, some of these drawers are hard to open.
There we go! The first drawer is cracked.
And… A training manual? On codes and ciphers. Might be helpful.
Nothing too exciting in the other drawers. A few more MREs which are always welcome.
I'm not keen on climbing into another maintenance shaft, considering how the last one went... But maybe it's worth it..?
Try the shaft!
Return to the Hub.
Whew. Okay, suck it up, Anosova. This tight, enclosed space can't hurt you more than it already has.
Ow -- Banged by my elbow.
Oh boy... That claustrophobia developed quickly. It's tighter in here than I thought.
Light! Finally, the end of the tunnel --
Leading into the airlock?
Outside of the massive hole in the ground, it held together pretty well.
Not much in here, but I can salvage some wire from the toolkit.
I can wedge open the airlock doors from here. No more crawling for me, thank you very much.
Okay, time to regroup with the others.
Back in the Hub of the Soyuz, we look like a sorry state.
Burkov attempts to muster as much gusto and charisma as he can. It doesn't go far.
"Pavlovsky, have you determined our location?" Burkov asks.
"Not as of yet. By the looks of things, we're in the Siberian. But our damn -- "
Smack! -- He hits a monitor.
"GPS still reads that we're about 620 000 kilometers in the air."
"It seems we'll be waiting here a while."
What do you mean, "waiting?"
You think the Soviet Union is going to rescue us?
"We're in a survival situation. Our best option is to stay put. Someone will come." Burkov remarks.
"Not if they don't know where we are." Pavlvosky retorts.
"Well, I'm open to suggestions." Burkov responds.
"There's a tower in the west. Looks like a radio." Vasiliev says.
"We might be better making for the mountain to the west. It would give us a view of our surroundings."
The mountain seems safer, but the radio tower might give us a shot at actually contacting someone.
Let's head towards the radio tower.
The mountain's our best bet.
"Well, the mountain seems like the better option... So we're a hung jury on this one," Burkov says.
"No offence, Commander, but I trust Anosova on this one," Pavlovsky says.
Burkov goes quiet. His cold expression gives away nothing. "Alright, the tower it is," he finally says.
"We should get moving shortly. We need to catch whatever daylight we can."
Into the white hell...
Oh, that looks like a tight squeeze. Okay, here we go.
Wow, is it ever bright out here. Everything is white. The snowflakes are enormous.
It looks like we've crash-landed in a forest. Bits of shrapnel surround our ship... And it looks like something huge came off the Soyuz as we were landing. I can't quite make it out.
There's a trail of disturbed snow leading towards whatever it is, though.
Enough sightseeing, I need to find somewhere warm. My jumpsuit is doing nothing for this cold.
The inside of the Soyuz is a disaster... It's not even the right way up.
"Only my pride..." He coughs violently.
No sense in going back out there.
Where should I explore next?
There's nothing left that's useful in there.
Should I continue to explore the Soyuz?
That airlock is still jammed.
I've already opened every drawer on this ship. There's nothing left for me.
Anything left to do in the storage compartment?
I am not getting back into that shaft.
I may have overestimated my abilities here. He's really high up there.
Whoah... These branches are not sturdy.
I'm not sure I can make it to him.
There's no sense in breaking my neck.
He would get me down. I have to keep trying.
I hate leaving him, but I think that was the right call.
I should follow that trail.
I'm not sure about this...
Okay, I'm just about there.
He looks even worse up close...
I'm just going to try and --
Snap.
Crunch.
"I-I'm not sure. I remember an explosion after the parachute got released."
"I think I got sucked out of the ship when the door came off. It took most of the damage."
"I've got some good news. I found our last cosmonaut." Shouts, Pavlovsky.
"Vasiliev, you're alive..?"
"Don't sound so excited." He retorts.
It's not that, just when I didn't see you...
My bad.
"Shame about Kamkin. He was a good kid." Vasiliev remarks.
"Let me have a look at your shoulder. I found a medkit while you were out." Pavlovsky calls.
"I can handle it."
"If that's what you want," Pavlovsky says while handing over the medkit.
"They will. The Soviets don't abandon their own." Burkov replies
Pavlovsky straightens himself out beside the monitor, awkwardly trying to fill Burkov's boots.
"So, uh, it's down to the three of us," Pavlovsky says. "Our GPS is completely fried, which leaves us alone out here."
"We're fucked?" Kamkin asks, rather calmly.
"Not fucked per se, but the Soviets aren't going to search the entire Siberian Wilderness to find us."
What are our options then?
You don't think they're coming?
"There's a mountain west of here. It would give us a view of our surroundings," Pavlosky says.
"I saw a radio tower to the east, it would give us a better chance of actually getting help," says Kamkin
"Without Burkov, we're leaderless," Pavolvsky explains, "you might as well be the tiebreaker."
The radio tower sounds safer.
Let's make for the mountains.
"It's decided. We should try and leave soon... We've lost enough hours as is.
Into the white hell...
"It's decided then. We'll leave for the mountain as soon as we can."
We left the Soyuz within the hour. On our way towards the icy peak.
The climate is treacherous. The wind rips at our clothes.
I can feel the cold in my bones.
After hiking for a few hours, the mountain seems just as far as it did when we left the ship.
The forest has thinned out, offering no protection against the elements.
"We should think about stopping for the night," Burkov suggests.
"We'd freeze if we tried to camp here. We're too exposed," Pavlovsky retorts, "we should push on.
"It's not too late to turn back," Kamkin suggests.
"We didn't come all this way to turn back," says Pavovlsky
We should take shelter while we still have energy.
There's no sense stopping while there's light.
I think the radio tower's our best bet.
The rock makes the tent hard to pitch.
Eventually, we get a fire started.
The mood is low. Everyone's exhausted.
I'm the last to turn in. Hopefully, tomorrow will be better.
The light is dying, but we're still making good progress.
Oh, God. It's Vasiliev.
Kamkin's gone... But Burkov's still with us.
"I saw a radio tower to the west. Might be operational." Kamkin says.
"I suppose Anosova has a brilliant plan to get us out of this," Vasiliev scoffs.
I just might. That is unless you wanted to share yours first?
Yeah, I do. It involves you going and --
"There's a radio tower to the west," Pavolvsky interjects.
Vasiliev laughs, "I would rather head to the mountain in the west. It could show us what we're dealing with."
"It's decided then. We'll leave for the mountain as soon as we can."
We left the Soyuz within the hour. On our way towards the icy peak.
The climate is treacherous. The wind rips at our clothes.
I can feel the cold in my bones.
After hiking for a few hours, the mountain seems just as far as it did when we left the ship.
The forest has thinned out, offering no protection against the elements.
"We need to take shelter before the sun goes down," Vasiliev shouts over the storm.
"We still have a few hours of sun," responds Pavlovsky. "This mountain isn't getting any closer. We could turn back?"
"We're staying course!"
"Well, we might freeze if we tried camping here! We're too exposed."
Make shelter for the night.
Keep pushing forward.
Head back for the radio tower.
No sense in losing our heads over a couple of lost hours. The radio tower was the better decision from the beginning.
Time to trek back. Onwards towards the tower.
We can't stop now. The air is frigid, and our tent won't stand up against the direct wind.
There seems to be a dirt road ahead.
It goes along the side of the mountain to the west and leads back towards the radio tower to the east.
"Th-that road," Burkov stammers, "might lead to a town."
"We would have better luck following it back to the tower," Pavlovsky says.
"It would make for an easy hike," Kamkin responds.
We need to keep pushing.
The road to the tower seems safer.
We continue to trudge up the mountain.
I can feel my fingers turning blue, nails turning black.
The howling of the wind drowns out even my footsteps.
The view had better be worth it.
"We're an embarrassment. The Soviet Union doesn't stick it's neck out for its failures," Pavlovsky says.
"We don't know that," Kamkin says.
"Our options are limited."
"It's not too late to turn back," Vasiliev says.
"That's a lot of retracing," Vasiliev says, "Though it would be easy."
Upon returning to the Hub, there seems to be another person with Pavovsky..?
"Should we think about finding shelter?" Kamkin shouts.
"We can't turn back."
You fell and broke your neck. Beats freezing to death I suppose.
You froze in your sleep. Guess they weren't kidding about your tent being three seasons...
Your body shut down in excruciating pain as you reached the peak. You didn't even get to the top...
I'll give it a try.
One more go...
I throw my arms around him.
CHAPTER 2
The River
We only got a couple of hours in yesterday before the light disappeared.
We found an alcove to pitch a tent in. The trees protected from the elements.
Nobody had a great sleep, but we're all still alive.
Which is great because we it was bitterly cold. At least we all still have all our fingers.
By the looks of it, the radio tower isn't more than a days hike away.
The group has stopped ahead of me.
As I approach, Kamkin takes off his boot and empties what must be a gallon of sweat onto the trail.
"That's disgusting! You couldn't have done that away from us?" Pavlovsky asks.
"You wanna hike in sweat, that's your prerogative, man," responds Kamkin.
"So why have we stopped?" Asks Burkov.
"Anosova was falling behind," Pavlovsky says, "Wanted to give her a chance to catch up."
Shove it, Pavlovsky.
I was watching our rear.
"Whoah, not a morning person, noted," Pavlvosky says.
"From all the way back there?" Pavlovsky says.
"All right, settle down kids," Burkov interrupts "Pavlovsky scout ahead for the best trail. Let's take a moment here to rest."
Pavlvosky grumbles as he disappears into the thicket.
You've got a daughter, right Burkov?
How are you holding up, old man?
"That's right, Sara. She turns 11 in a couple of days. This'll be the first year I've missed the party."
"Fit as a fiddle. No where I'd rather be."
Before I can respond, Pavlovsky shouts from the distance, "You guys had better come see this."
We push our way through the underbrush to see Pavlovsky a little ways down the trail.
As we near, it looks like he's standing on a ridge --
One that stretches in either direction for miles.
As we near, it becomes clear that what looked like a ridge is actually a deep gorge with a river at the bottom.
"And you thought the hike was going to be easy," Pavlovsky mocks.
"That rest may be longer than I anticipated," Burkov says.
We should search along the ravine for a way across.
We should look for a way down.
"If you think you'll find something, go ahead," Burkov says.
"I'll give you a hand," Pavlovsky says.
Hurry up then.
I could use the help.
I set off along the ridge with Pavlovsky.
The gorge is shockingly deep. It would take some time to try and climb down there.
"We made the right decision leaving that shuttle," Pavlovsky says, "the Union would never have found us."
Not with our GPS smashed.
You don't think so?
"Even otherwise, the Soviets have a way of forgetting things that go wrong."
"I wish I didn't, but there was no chance."
"I worked as a weapons developer for long enough to know what’s considered a stain on their reputation."
The Soviet's don't abandon their people.
It doesn't mean they'd leave us.
"You know, I worked with your father."
"I didn't tell you earlier because I didn't want it to influence what you thought of me."
Pavlovsky pulls a metal briefcase out of his backpack and hands it to me.
What's this?
Thanks, but no thanks.
"Every Soviet space shuttle is equipped with one of these."
He opens it up to reveal a triple-barreled pistol.
"This is called a TP-82, the engineers thought we might want a little help... You know, in the case that we crash in the Siberian wilderness. It has a machete built into the stock."
"Don't tell Burkov you've got it. You and me, we think alike."
"The old man would turn his mother in if she went against Soviet rhetoric."
Thanks..?
No promises.
Holy shit..."
No way..."
Ahead of us, like a mirage, an old maintenance bridge sways In the wind.
It creaks softly.
"It looks pretty decrepit, but it's still mostly intact, which means it probably safe to cross."
"Either that or we climb down into the ravine, which no doubt would be safer, though may take some time."
"What do you think? Should we call the others over? Or should we find a way down into the gorge?"
Let's cross that bridge.
Absolutely not crossing that thing. Let's climb down into the ravine.
We gather around the bridge like a bunch of nervous kids, all daring each to do something stupid.
"You're confident it's safe?" Burkov asks.
"I wouldn't say confident," Pavlovsky says, "but I believe it's used to access that tower, which means it is likely tested regularly."
"I'm hearing a lot of maybes," Burkov responds.
"I'll go," Kamkin interjects.
"Are you sure, I don't want you to feel --" Burkov starts.
"If one of you goes first, it'll take away that rush of uncertainty," Kamkin responds.
"Well, I'm not going to stop you."
Kamkin claps Burkov's back before stepping up to the bridge.
He flashes us a cheesy grin before stepping out onto the wood panelling.
It groans under his weight. Gripping the rope siding, he cautiously crosses.
The bridge creaks and cracks with every step he takes.
Wind rips at him, tugging at his suit.
Midway across, he steps down and the board splinters --
He grasps at the rope-siding madly as the broken plank plummets into the raging river below.
He continues across, finally reaching the other side.
"Looks like our best bet," Burkov says. "I'll head across with a rope, and we'll ferry our packs first, and then you two can follow."
Burkov takes a line of the rope and walks over to the bridge. He crosses it slowly, methodically.
The wind rips at the bridge, causing it to sway gut-wrenchingly.
He safely steps onto the west side of the cliff, beside Kamkin.
Behind me, Pavlovsky has gone pale.
You there?
Are you scared of something?
"Oh, sorry. I, uh, thought I saw something...
"Scared? No, of course not."
"Okay, well, give me a hand tying these packs to the rope, so that we can ferry them to the other side."
"Will do."
"We're going to have to pull them slowly; we can't afford to lose any bags."
One by one, supported the line as Burkov and Kamkin pulled from the other side.
"Slow down, Pavlovsky!"
The packs come to a halt halfway across. They've caught on the siding of the bridge,
"Dammit, Pavlovsky."
The pack jostles, Burkov, and Kamkin are still pulling from the other side.
"The pack's going to fall if they keep pulling!" Pavlovsky shouts.
"I'm going out there to pull it loose!"
Or I can rush, but that might lead to an accident...
Take this one slow.
This calls for a quick approach.
The bridge sways dauntingly ahead of me, as I take my first step.
Okay, this is nothing, just breath...
The backpack is only a little further...
No big deal, the fall might not kill me. If I'm lucky, I'll only break several bones.
Burkov yells something, though I can't hear it over the wind.
In a few feet I should be able to reach it --
SNAP!
I turn to see the support pillar break loose --
It slams into Pavlovsky, knocking him onto the bridge.
I don't even have time to react before the entire structure collapses.
Rushing water, rapids, gasping --
SLAM!
I'm blindly fumbling to grasp whatever I just collided with.
It's a massive rock. I'm able to pull myself out of the water, enough that I can see a riverbank not too far away.
Try to get to the shore.
Climb higher on to the rock.
Here goes nothing --
Hah hah...
I made it... I'm on dry ground!
There's something in the water!
It looks like Pavlovsky!
Dive in after him!
Look for something to toss him.
I'm going back in.
Oh shit, he's way heavier than I thought he'd be.
Back on the shore...
It's not even Pavlovsky. It's our fucking pack!
"Anna!" I hear a shout from the river.
Pavlovsky is stranded on the rock I collided with.
Without thinking, I wade into the river and reach for his arm.
I'm barely able to stand, but I manage to get him to shore.
We both collapse.
Pavlovsky... Are you alright?
Why didn't you listen when I told you not to tug the pack?
"Alright..? No, I'm not alright!"
…This is my fault? It was your idea to try the damn bridge!
He pushes himself up with his arms.
His right arm bends in on itself -- He slams back into the ground.
"SON OF A -- "
I rush over to help him up.
"My fucking arm! It’s broken! goddamn bridge!"
Hold still!
We’ve got to splint it!
Pavlovsky shoves me backwards, I land on my butt.
"Fuck off!" He shouts.
You need medical attention!
Fuck it, splint it yourself!
Bushes along the river rustle in the wind.
"I don't need any more help from you!"
"Hey! I didn't crash our ship."
I start digging through the surviving packs. Luckily the case I pulled out of the river had some climbing gear.
In my backpack, I pull out the medkit and the TP-82's case. Something catches my eye in the reflection of the case --
I look awful. My face is just riddled with bruises.
Honestly, considering the circumstances, of well, falling from space, I look pretty damn fine.
Behind my reflection, though, are the bushes. Two hungry yellow eyes look back at me through the mirror -- A wolf!
It lunges at me.
Swing the case at it.
Attempt to open it to access the TP-82.
I swing the case around, and it slams into the wolf's head.
The wolf yelps as it careens off to the side.
It bares its teeth at me, growling.
I hesitantly open the TP-82 case, reaching inside for the pistol.
Shoot the wolf.
Fire a warning shot.
BANG!
For a moment, all sound dies down as the wolf collapses to the ground.
"That won't be the only one..." Pavlvosky mutters.
I don't see any others.
"They travel in packs. That one was probably here to test us..."
"We can't stay here."
We'll need to find a way up.
Oh, here I thought we could just hang out down here, freezing to death.
"I don't know if I can walk, let alone climb."
"But it would be risky to spend too much time down here, considering the wolves..."
The remainder of the bridge hangs from the west cliff, taunting us.
"Or... We could try climbing up what's left of the bridge?" I suggest.
"Are you insane?"
"Plus, it would beat getting eaten by wolves."
"I'll wait here, thank you."
You're right, we should stay down here and rest.
I'll toss you a rope from up top.
"You've lost it."
I hold out the TP-82 pistol to Pavlovsky before tossing him a bottle of painkillers.
If you see any wolves, just point and shoot.
Use those painkillers sparingly, they're all we have.
Pavlovsky looks down at the pistol, alarmed.
"I'm not a child."
Without looking back, I'm already tightening the rope around my waist.
The climbing gear is rudimentary, but it should suffice.
The remainder of the bridge sways above me, a dozen or so feet out of reach.
It seems like I could rely on the bridge to help me up most of the way once I reach it.
That being said, the bridge hasn't proved itself exceptionally helpful at keeping me suspended.
Use the bridge to scale the cliff.
Rely on sheer climbing ability.
As they say, fool me once…
I drive my makeshift pick into the icy cliffside. It makes a surprisingly supportive hold.
One hand, after the other, I slowly make my way up to the bridge.
Luckily once you've spacewalked, your ego is so big that you think you can scale a fucking cliff.
Hopefully, my hubris doesn't bite me.
Okay, I made it to the bottom of the hanging bridge.
The panelling creaks unhelpfully as I pull myself so that I'm standing on it.
Alright, this is the easy part, right?
Just like climbing a ladder...
Except that at any point the entire structure could collapse down on to -- If I'm lucky -- Solid ground.
I can barely hold on! The entire bridge is blowing so much in the wind. I --
CRASSH
Shit. Fuck. I'm okay. The panel I was on didn't especially like being my lifeline it turns out.
But I've got hold of the rope.
Just about there...
I made it! Solid ground.
Now I've just got to toss down that rope to Pavlovsky, and we're off to the races.
I tug the rope, helping Pavlovsky get up the side of the cliff.
I'm nearing exhaustion, not sure how much more of this I can do.
Suddenly his hand appears on the edge of the cliff and with one more pull, he's beside me.
Hah hah.
"...Fuck space," he finally gets out.
We both laugh coarsely.
Couldn’t have said it better myself.
I'd take space any day over that cliff.
"I supposed you're going to tell me we need to get a move on?"
That's right.
We can rest a moment.
"That's what I like to hear."
"That was pretty insane, taking on that wolf…"
"Where'd you learn to use a gun?"
I used to go hunting... With my father.
It's not hard.
"It was just a question."
"Didn't your father pass when you were six or seven?"
Nothing wrong with learning early.
We should get going...
"No, I suppose there isn't."
"Well, we should get moving if we're going to catch up with the crew."
"It looks like there's a trail leading into the forest, which is probably them."

Let's follow their trail.
Along the gorge seems like the best option.
Okay, into the forest it is.

I hope they didn't get injured.
God willing, they're at the end of this trail...
Pavlovsky is already lagging.
There's a light in the distance!
As we near, the murmuring from the fire goes silent.
It's just us!
(Stay hidden)
"Anna?" Burkov calls out as he stands up, as if on alert.
"How did you..?" Kamkin starts to ask.
It involved fighting a wolf.
You don't believe I could survive falling into a gorge and scaling a cliff?

Thank you.
I didn't know you had to cook them.

They creak with my weight but remain stable.
I reach the tangled pack quickly.
A sudden gust of wind catches the bridge.
Yank the pack loose.
Hold steady.
It's really caught...
After a second... It comes loose!
The wind begins to pick up.
I twist my arms around the rope to hold on, lest the wind tries to knock me off.
SNAP!
While holding, I turn to see the support pillar break loose --
It slams into Pavlovsky, knocking him onto the bridge.
The other support pillar follows. The entire structure collapses.
With my arms tangled in the rope, I hold on as the bridge swings down and slams into the western cliff.
The force of the impact winds me.
I almost let go, if not for how secure my arms are in the rope-siding.
I'm still catching my breath when I look up to see an arm reaching down for me.
Struggling to move, I'm able to climb the rope-siding, carefully.
The pack is cumbersome. It's making it difficult to climb the bridge with it.
Keep carrying the pack.
Drop it into the gorge.
It's going to be hard.
My shoulder is killing me. The pack rubs against the gash with every inch.
The planks are holding steady...
But I'm on the verge of collapsing.
I don't know if I can do it...
My grip is loosing --
A hand reaches down and grabs hold as I'm letting go.
I'm pulled up onto the west cliff side.
A face looks down at me. It almost looks like my father's...
"Anna! Are you hurt?" Burkov calls.
Burkov..?
No more than usual.
"What the hell were you thinking?" Burkov yells. "You almost got killed!"
"For a backpack of all things!"
"Come on, Burkov, that's not fair," Kamkin says.
"Of course, it is! That was reckless!"
"She didn't know the bridge would fucking give in!"
Burkov rubs his face and walks away.
"Nothing looks broken, but you're probably in shock," Kamkin says, kneeling beside me.
Is Pavlovsky..?
You both are fine?
Kamkin shakes his head.
"He fell in… We didn't see him after he landed in the river..."
"I don't think he..." Kamkin breaks off.
That's horrible.
Kamkin nods sullenly.
Burkov returns and looks out over the edge of the cliff.
"I'm torn..." Burkov starts, "We don't have spare resources or time..."
"We can try to go back for him, though it may hurt our chances in the long run..."
"Or we have to assume the worse, knowing there's little chance he survived that fall...
Burkov looks at me, with a deep sadness in his eyes.
We have to go back for him.
There's no way he survived.
We sit, quiet for a moment, nobody quite sure what to say.
"What now?" Kamkin says, breaking the silence.
"I suppose we make camp for the night. Let's find somewhere to make a fire in the forest.
It doesn't take long to find a secluded area and to get a fire roaring.
There is a new heaviness in the air.
"Pavlovsky was a good man. He was a Soviet through and through," Burkov says.
"Another body unburied..." Kamkin says
I didn't know him as well as I'd have liked to. Maybe in the next life.
The best Soviet I've ever known.
Kamkin and Burkov raise their survival cups in a toast.
"We won't let his struggle go to waste," Burkov says.
Few words were exchanged over the rest of the night.
Burkov and Kamkin shift uncomfortably.
A beacon of hope...
Burkov nods, "we're not leaving somebody behind."

You're trusting that rope?

"One of us should wait up here."
It should be Kamkin
Burkov had better wait.

Kamkin ties up a line using the rope from the bridge.

The wind rips at our backs during the descent.
Thanks to the anchor Kamkin prepared for the rope, the wind doesn't affect us much.
We finally reach the rocky beach.

"We should look around here," Burkov calls, "see if we can't find out where he is."
"He would have fallen in a little upstream from here."
Search near the water.
Look along the beach.
Try downstream.

A piece of fabric!
It looks like it belongs to one of our jumpsuits.

There's some mud, but nothing unusual.
...Hold on, there are a couple of crimson drops.

Check by the old log.
Search along the beach.
Try the underbrush.
Go back upstream.

There's something caught in one of the branches.

There's a trail of blood here...

I really hope they belong to Pavlovsky, and we're not about to come face to face with an injured wolf...

Okay...
We're through.

I'll cut away the underbrush blocking it.

The four of us take a moment to rest at the top of the cliff.

"Let's find somewhere to make a fire and camp for the night," says Burkov.
It doesn't take long to find a secluded area and to get a fire roaring.

We sit around the fire and share a meal.
"I was very determined not to freeze to death."
His arms are coated in blood from small cuts.

"Let's get you out of here."

Let's do it.
We should keep looking.
The crew stands around the switchbacks, looking uneasy at the prospect.

I'll go first.
I'll keep watching the back.

We line up, ready to face our greatest fear --
A slight decline on unstable shale.
Kamkin leads us, with Burkov close behind. Pavlovsky's slower, which means I have to stay back.

Are you alright?

No, I'll stay back here.
